Author: Julian Lloyd
Message:
Initialize element revealed state

Fixes #468

The `sync()` method exposed a bug where calling `reveal(target)`
on the same `target` would break animation.

This was due to `element.revealed` staying `true` inspite of being
reinitialized. Although this fixes #468, element initialization
logic seems too spread across the `reveal` and `initialize` fns.

Author: Julian Lloyd
Message:
cache method getters

I recall testing the `rinse()` fn (specifically the removal of
event listeners), and thinking "sweet, now this is working"...

But as I spotted here, `bind(context, fn)` returns a new function,
so I'm not sure how `removeEventListener` was ever working...

This deserves some more testing, but for now, gut says cache those
method getters.

Author: Julian Lloyd
Message:
revert sequencer refactor

This reverts commit 2d49e4bf374e39a293eb8f7a58261ab996283903.

The beta.26 release sequencer changes included logical regressions,
resulting in sequence intervals being ignored if the window was
scrolled at certain (and common) speeds.

The refactor should be moved into its own branch..

Author: J.L. Makes

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
refactor sequencer

The sequencer up until now has honored DOM order, which doesn't
handle more unusual layouts (such as the ScrollReveal demo, or
layouts created using CSS Grid).

This refactor refocuses the sequencer on visible order, which
for most layouts will not have any noticeable difference... but
dramatically improves the sequencer's flexibility for layouts
with elements outside of DOM order.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
bind methods as read-only instance properties

Consider this fragment:

```js
nodes.forEach(n => ScrollReveal().clean(n))
```

Because we're working with a singleton instance, there's no need
to leverage the prototype... and instead, using bound read-only
methods, we enable the following:

```js
nodes.forEach(ScrollReveal().clean)
```

Message:
patch matrix interpolation browser bug [closes #350]

Thereâ€™s a Chromium and Firefox bug when it comes to matrix
interpolation, which breaks CSS transitions:

https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=729010

This commit is a simple workaround that emulates the correct
behavior, just by using a near-zero value when zero is passed.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
instance methods are no longer chainable

Truthfully, method chaining was added because it was easy to do...
but it adds virtually no value.

sr.reveal('foo')
  .reveal('bar')

vs.

sr.reveal('foo')
sr.reveal('bar')

The methods don't impact other parts of the chain as they do in
a library like jQuery, and by not supporting method chaining, it
opens up interesting opportunities to store reveals in variables;
this could allow for manual control over reveal state, adding
support for things like fullPage.js and other 3rd party libraries.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
replace explicit animate call from initialize

The handler function calls animate in the next animation frame,
so it's unecessary to import and invoke animate explicitly.
Moreover, the call to animate doesn't accurately describe the
flow of logic...

As the handler functions grows beyond simply calling animate
inside request animation frame, the new functionality will still
almost certainly be relevant after intialization; the true need
is not a one-time animate call, but a one-time handler call to
capture the initial state.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
change container store array to object literal

After reviewing element visibility checks in version 3, I noticed
the container scroll position and dimensions were fetched for each
element... when in any given animation frame, those values won't
change.

Instead, version 4 will store container nodes, scroll position and
dimensions behind an object key (id), and each element will know
the id of its container.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
add tentative new android 4.4 config

SauceLabs is an awesome, yet horribly frustrating service. After
much pain, I've uncovered a seemingly correct Android 4.4
configuration... but there's an SSL warning/popup on the Google
Android emulator URL that prevents the tests from running.

I don't understand why this has become so difficult, and why the
configuration block for Android 4.4 has to be significantly
different than Android 4.2 and every other browser I test against.

Either way, when I manually close the popup the test does indeed
pass on Android 4.4.2, so this configuration is correct, it's just
commented out for now until the SSL error is sorted.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
remove iife from instance defaults and noop export

This change causes tests to fail, even though bundling has no
issues. It's possible there is something odd about karma rollup
preprocessor (which I maintain), but it turns out that the bug
is easily fixed by updating a regex within Rollup:

https://github.com/rollup/rollup/pull/1218

So it appears the next release of Rollup following 0.40.0 will
no longer fail tests due to this strange issue with object literal
default exports.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
extract transform matrix values into array

This is getting into a bit of deep shit, in order to finally
resolve #251 and preserve CSS transforms. I've successfully
captured the computed transformation matrix as a 16 value array...
even when the shorthand is provided.

Definitely looking promising, but this is just the first step.
Next I will need to generate a matrix from the `reveal()` config,
which appears to be the biggest hurdle.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
relax rAF polyfill test to accept 1 extra call

Using Date.now() seems to be fairly reliable, but in some cases
the callcount is 7 instead of the desired 6 within 96ms (60fps).
I think a slightly more lenient test is acceptable, all things
considered. After all, it is still throttling callback calls at
a rate of ~60fps.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
replace karma browserify plugin with rollup

The goal is to be testing the same code that's shipping to users,
since the Browserify code is horribly bloated -- I measured the
file size to be DOUBLE that of rollup. Not to mention that
Browserify was using Babel, whereas the distribution was using
Buble...

Suffice to say, the frustration was worth the confidence that what
is being shipped, is what is being tested. (It also means my code
coverage looks a lot more like the source.)

An example benefit of this strategy, is that I've identified the
Object.assign method as needing a polyfill, and that the spread
operator on NodeLists does not work with Buble.

Some tests are failing in this build, but that will be rectified
shortly, as the next few commits will be focused on a polyfill
for Object.assign....

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
add browserify.bundleDelay to karma config

Seems that OSX has weird timing with file system changes, and was
causing a bug where each save would trigger tests twice. Now using
bundle delay, tests correctly only trigger once per save.

Message:
add new core getContainerElement() function

Since ScrollReveal supports DOM nodes and selector strings to
define custom container elements, this function accepts both nodes
and selector strings and returns the correct element...

Or returns null and logs what went wrong.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
update which browsers are tested by sauce labs

Encore! I'm still experimenting with test times, and to be frank,
what looks good in the README. I've decided to test one relatively
old version of each platform, in good faith of support in future
versions.

Also, Sauce Labs takes over 4 minutes to spin up Mobile Safari 10,
which just seemed pointless. I think this is the last time I'll
have to fiddle with the SauceLabs browser config.

'Ey!

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
add constructor unit test

Dang, code coverage is awesome! I noticed that the instantiated
object was not being tested when ScrollRreveal isn't supported.

I made a few changes to be able to stub the method checking for
support, and also to the noop instance so that it still has noop
public methods.

The noop instance should prevent runtime errors on browsers that
don't support CSS Transition and Transform. One could check that
the `sr` class has been added to `<html>`, but this approach
allows the developer to be optimistic.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message: update which browsers are tested by sauce labs

Author: J.L. Makes
Message: remove dots reporter from karma config

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
simplify npm test scripts

The SauceLabs tunnel runs like absolute trash locally (sorry), and
the difference between a PhantomJS test and all 27 browser-device
combinations when ran through Travis CI... is less than 2 minutes.

In other words, I've removed the ability to run Sauce Labs testing
locally, and instead refactored the scripts to detect the TRAVIS
environment variable; npm test will invoke the SauceLabs launcher
when ran by Travis CI, and use only PhantomJS when ran locally.

There is only `npm test` and `npm run testing` which appends the
--auto-watch flag to Karma. Booya!

Author: J.L. Makes
Message: add sauce labs browser matrix to README

Message: fix markdown errors with travis badge

Author: J.L. Makes
Message: add travis build status badge to README

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
add complete browser list to sauce labs launcher

The first Travis CI build passed! Hallelujah, everything appears
to be configured correctly... now time to turn up the heat.

This commit introduces over 20 browser-device combinations, and
help test the reliability of Travis CI and Saucelabs together.

Note, the .travis.yml still has inverted if statements during
these trial runs... once confirmed, PhantomJS will be the default
testing environment for commits, and Sauce Labs for PRs.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
install and configure karma, sauce labs and travis-ci

All of the work on integrating rollup into the build process for
distribution files, created some friction when trying to integrate
Karma. Due to better support, I've added Browserify to the test
preprocessors for Karma, and anticipate refactoring the gulp build
tasks with it as well.

In fact, the "mocha in browser" approach seemed to fall flat once
I looked at introducing Sauce Labs for cross browser testing...
and now I understand where Karma fits into the ecosystem!

Unfortunately, it means some pretty dramatic refactoring had to
happen, undoing some of the past month's work... and there's still
more refactoring to be done.

That said, everything appears to be working locally with Karma and
Sauce Labs, and the next step is confirming that Travis CI is
setup correctly alongside the two.

Author: J.L. Makes

Author: J.L. Makes

refactor build tasks using rollup-stream

In order to use gulp plugins like uglify() and stripDebug(), with
rollup, the distribution task was refactored to use rollup-stream.

In the process, gulp-rename and pump were removed.

Author: J.L. Makes
Message:
author new change log

The original change log did not include anything prior to v2.0.0,
and bundled patch notes into minor notes. These decisions,
alongside a number of code samples showing deprecated code
prompted this overhaul.

The new format is based off http://keepachangelog.com, and
includes all work from launch to present in a consistent fashion.
